The Most Important achievements in Video Game History

Wolfenstein and Doom Created the basic of the first person gaming experience. 
Opening doors and searching for key became the standard for the genre it self. (Quake, Duke 3d, Shadow warrior ect)

But on November 8, 1998 Half Life Change everything. It was no longer about searching for keys it became more about A First Person Narrative that didn't exist before in the gaming industry. There was no cut sceen only direct contact whit the environment and caracters that you encounterd. It was a personal story about crowbars, jumping, crawling in vent and survival. The user/player was Gordon freeman, you have a PHD in theoretical physics, you blew up the microwave of you colleague and  yes you brought chaos at Black Mesa, before the even began.


It was a Daring Aproache but one that paid off, it was a changing point in the FPS genre and viewed by many has one of the Best Video Game ever made.
In this day and age The FPS Genre is the Cow Milk of the industry and game like Half Life are Rare and are not the standart of the Gaming industry but they should be. 


10/10: Verdict: A MasterPiece

This game build an empire but not just because, it's well structured, long enough, hard enough and you have the chance to play as the iconic Morgan Freeman,

Anyway even it's and old game it's still supported and have aged very well, if you haven't play it it's a must for all gamers.

作为我人生中第一款打通的PC游戏，半条命的剧情绝对是在我心中深深印着的，当时的PC游戏大多数类型都是像DOOM、QUAKE这种快节奏无脑突突突游戏，当然不得不承认真的很吸引人，直到98年，一家名叫V社的公司发布了他们的第一款游戏，他的名字就叫做半条命。他在当时有着顶级的画面及音效，以及出色的人工AI，敌人会包抄你，受伤时会撤退，这在当时DOOM狂潮的游戏里绝对算得上是一股泥石流，但是这里我要说一下，半条命并不是当时第一款主讲剧情的游戏，有兴趣的玩家可以试试找一下网络奇兵这款游戏（当然我们的正题还是半条命啦）半条命讲述的是在199X年，黑山实验基地希望做一次实验（姑且就这么说吧。。我也不是学霸。。）然而科学家作死把本来反应堆的参数从85%调到了105%，然后发生了串联共振现象，把xen的怪物给送到地球了，人型自走挂Freeman为了生存不得不拿起武器与怪物和政府对抗最后把怪物老家给端了的故事。游戏最大的特点就是在当时加入了双结局设定，这让当时只玩过DOOM的我给惊了一把，在一款当时的线型游戏里有一点自由度都是划时代的。半条命也无愧与最佳PC游戏的称号，两个字：经典。

Half-Life.  Where Valve started.  This is the game that put them on the map and the game that eventually spawned the entire engine and framework that is used for all of Valves games (Team Fortress 2, Half-Life 2, Garry's Mod, etc...).

Half-Life tells the story of science gone wrong, likely caused by some odd organizational force, as you'll discover through playing.  It tells the story through the eyes of Gordon Freeman, a scientist at the Black Mesa Research Facility.  The game essentially begins with a very interesting explosion, and from there on out, you are met with otherworldly creatures, and humans that only share the desire to kill you.  You must escape.  Save as many people as you can.  Stop the spread of these creatures that seem only hell-bent on destroying life as you know it.

Did I forget to mention the crowbar? 

Oh, I did?

There's a crowbar.  Use it, live it, love it.


I highly recommend this timeless FPS that really brought an interesting plot to the table with some great gameplay.

So here we are in 2015 and I FINALLY played Half Life. What took me so long? I don't know for sure but I'm mainly a console gamer.
This game lived up to its reputation and for a game made in 1998 it still packs a punch today. Even the AI is acceptable by todays standards. The guns are fantastic and have a great weighty feel to them.
When you consider that the brilliant Goldeneye 007 on Nintendo 64 came out in 1997 and Half Life just one year later this game has aged far far better. I now can't wait to start playing Half Life 2 and everybody knows that 3 is due only any day right...right?

[h1][b]                         [u]RESEÑA LIBRE DE SPOILERS [/u][/b][/h1]

Si te gustan los juegos retro, ni siquiera necesito decirlo, te lo recomiendo sin dudas ya que en este juego fue donde inicio todo, además de la saga en si, Valve presento este juego con un motor que en su época fue algo revolucionario, trayendo una nueva forma de ver los First Person Shooters. Además, gracias a este motor se pudieron crear varios mods, como USS Darkstar, Azure Sheep, Sven Coop y el ahora juego independiente "Counter-Strike".

Pero si hablamos del juego en si. HL1 tiene una jugabilidad bastante atractiva mesclando los puzles con su estilo shooter en donde debemos utilizar los pensamientos lógicos para sobrevivir a un entorno lleno de entidades hostiles y variables con distintas habilidades que nos dificultaran el trayecto en el juego a mano de un gran arsenal de armas a nuestra disposición. Este titulo también posee un modo multijugador deathmatch que era muy jugado en los cibercafés en su época, pero hoy en día la cantidad de jugadores debe ser nula.

Aunque sea un gran juego en su época, sigue teniendo puntos negativos como los siguientes:
[list]
[*]Los bugs en este juego no son muchos ni pocos, muchos de ellos son exploits del juego, pero no llegan a arruinar la experiencia.
[*]Su lenta introducción, que aunque sea interesante para conocer el entorno, sigue siendo molesto estar inactivo por tanto tiempo.
[*]El juego tiene una cantidad escasa de 2 entidades aliadas, una de ellas con 4 variaciones.
[*]En su beta, el juego poseía mas armas y muchísimos mas enemigos de los que hay en su versión final. Por limitaciones graficas, todo esto fue recortado.
[*]En PlayStation 2, hay una campaña cooperativa llamada “Decay” que permite jugar con 2 científicas. Este modo quedo por completo en el olvido.[/list]

El siguiente y ultimo punto no es positivo ni negativo, pero HL1 es un juego de 1998 y a muchos jugadores de hoy en día no les atrae este tipo de juegos antiguos. Valve hiso una [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/280] remasterización[/url] que no tuvo éxito, pero hoy en día gracias a la comunidad, se logro crear un mod independiente llamado Black Mesa el cual recrea todo el juego entero desde 0 de una manera inimaginable. Si eres una persona que quiere jugar este titulo pero con gráficos next-gen, te recomiendo que pases de este juego y pruebes [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/362890] Black Mesa[/url].

Ya know how everyone's waiting for Half-Life 3? 

Well, play this game, then play the other games, and you'll see why.

You still gotta start with this game, though.

As you can probably tell if you look at my profile, I have an undying love for Half-Life. The reason I only have 5 hours on record is because I have the authentic 1998 CD version. But I have to admit, the original game hasn't aged terribly well. If you ignore the bugs, you'll have a blast from the past. But I have to say I prefer HL2 and the episodes.

Deathmatch is fun for messing around with friends. That's all I really reccomend for the classic Half-Life games, just something to play because you feel like it. If you want an [b] experience [/b], go play Half-Life 2 and the episodes.

After having been a long time fan of Half Life 2 and it's episodes I only recently completed the original Half Life recently.

The thing that impressed me the most was how diverse and creative the level design was. This is something I've always loved about Half Life 2; how from hour to hour the mood and pacing changes so dramatically. I can see the beginnings of that here. 

However, the last 2 or 3 stages of the game have quite a few (in my opinion) poorly designed parts that are confusing and frustrating. If I had played this in it's hay-day it may have been a 5/5 but in retrospect I would give it a 3/5.

The origin of everyone's favourite crowbar-wielding, vent-crawling theoretical physicist. 

This game is amazing, in nearly every way. The level design is clever and intuitive, cleverly directing you between objectives without the use of floating arrows or map markers. Every level feels visually distinct, and the difficulty curve is well-balanced and ramps up steadily throughout the game. 

Half-Life's story is simple but engrossing, and is told without ever taking away player control. The pacing is extremely well-done, striking a good balance between firefights, exploring, and environmental puzzles. 

Jumping physics are solid, and the platforming sections are never frustrating (don't forget to quick-save before a tricky jump!). Guns and weapons handle well and feel powerful. Health and ammo pick-ups are well-spaced, providing enough tension caused by resource scarcity, but avoiding frustratingly long stretches of having low health or no ammo. 

The sound design is incredible, whether it's the sound of Gordon's footsteps on a metal grate, the moans of a headcrab zombie, or the resounding "BOOM!" of a shotgun.

Don't get me wrong this is still an amazing game. Well worth the cost but it's not perfect. For one the graphics are well less then amazing. It clearly shows that this is a fairly older game. Next is the glitches. I don't know if it was my computer or the game but at least 4 times through my play through I got stuck by invisible barriers and could not move in any direction. Saludos: Isidro
Greatest FPS game ever.

This game has been legendary since it's release in 1998, it has won over 50 game of the year of awards. If you have a pc of any kind, get this game. Because the story is good, it runs on a potato, there is fast-paced fun multiplayer, supports mods that make the game way better, and the whole game is fun.

And if you don't have another reason for half-life then heres this: Half-Life SDK. The ultimate tool to putting your ideas from pen to paper, to a three-dimensional world that supports 32-bit coloured textures, ambient sounds that is really immersive, a top-notch visibility engine so everymap you play in is optimized for your pc, and aswell as high-poly models that can be created. Half-Life SDK WILL be in your LIBRARY-TOOLS folder upon buying Half-Life, for only 10 dollars.

And in courtesy of Mapcore.org and Game Bannana, you can download maps to enhance your experience, or why not install a mod where you play as another black mesa employee, trying to escape the HECU marines aswell as the Xen creatures.

I will never regret purchasing this game, it has filled me with experiences that I can always relive with a click of the blue PLAY button that sits in your library as you are bored and want to play a fun game. Buy this game, I don't care if your broke, get a small loan from the mafia or get a big one from the bank, just buy it.

HALF-LIFE. WRITTEN REVIEW NOT COMPLETE

quote. Scientist: [playing with tie] Why do we all have to wear these ridiculous ties?. 

Developed by Valve and released in 1998

Pros and Cons

pros. Everything
cons. Nothing 

10/10 Masterpicece


STORYLINE
A mysterious Alien Artifact has been recovered and brought to a top-secret research facility in the Black Mesa. When newcomer Dr. Gordon Freeman is assigned to physically test the artifact, things go very wrong when the artifact opens a destructive and unstable portal to Xen, a planet in a different dimension. Gordon blacks out, and awakes in a now crippled and ruined research facility. When Freeman and the survivors of this ordeal discover the portal has allowed its inhabitants-deadly alien creatures-to enter the facility, they realise that they must call the government for help. The government, however, already has plans to contain this incident by silencing the witnesses. 

Half life's story is a very diverse and confusing one, but is still executed brilliantly. since Half Life does not rely on cut scenes, there are moments when subtle important plot references are hinted towards key features of the story, but these references can be left unnoticed especially on a first play-through. This really depends on the player and their play style if you are to notice these references. Therefore this game mechanic should not be seen as a flaw rather as an attempt to try something new that valve knew very well wouldn’t mix with everyone.

GAMEPLAY
Half life is the most influential First Person Game Ever Made. This is best exemplified through its game play mechanics. Let me explain. 

Growing up as a young grommet the only fps game I was familiar with was DOOM. At the time DOOM was piratically seen as the best pc game of all time. All fps games two follow copied the DOOM formula, all except half life. You see Doom had 

.NO Apparent storyline
.NO Interesting characters 
.NO Absorbing atmosphere [It felt very arcade like]
.And no real apparent goal

The game was really a stress reviler where you just shoot s.hit and blow c.unts up. Not saying DOOM is a bad game. DOOM is one of my favourite games its just that Half life beat DOOM at the fps formula in all ways by Half Life having 

.A fantastic and engaging story.
.A scary immersive atmosphere.
.A roster of witty and interesting characters.
.A simplified moving mechanic
.A mechanic where you could look up and down.{ thank F.UCK for that }
.A Mixture of action and Puzzles
.And a game with an apparent goal from the very start.

You see Half Life wasn’t one of those games where you would just shoot s.hit and blows c.unts up. Half Life was the first real fps game to feel like a immersive gaming experience. Therefore we have half life to thank for saving and changing what was commonly thought of as the First Person Shooter Genre.

PACING
Half Life Pacing is Executed very well. The game has the whole survival horror game feel to it and the game really exemplifies this through a sense of dread. At the start of the game it is apparent that you need to escape the black mesa facility but only an hour down the track you start to lose recognition of that thought and just have the mindset of surviving, and that is why this games pacing is so good. You never quite feel like you have an objective to do rather you just feel you have to survive. and coupling this with the fine selection of jump-scares and mind blowing scripted events it truly holds up. 

LEVEL DESIGN 
Valve has a name for level design in their games. Its hard to describe on paper but no gaming developer team does it like valve, you just have to see it for yourself, I mean talk about attention to detail. Before Half Life level design in fps video games were very simplistic and felt like an arcade experience. Half Life's level design was truly ahead of its time. Structures would collapse, you could interact with all most everything from the environment, and the game used a clever use of scripted events through the level design. It is very hard to explain on paper but you can tell a lot of work was put into this category of game design for half life.

IMMERSION
Immersion, Probably The Fundamental Aspect Of Game Design That Every Game Director Should Take Seriously, Gabe Newell Certainty Did With Half-Life. You See Half-Life Never Breaks The Immersion Because The Game Never Allows The Player To Stop Playing. This Is Because The Game Doesn't Consist Of Cut-Scenes Or Any Other Immersion Breakers. The Game Never Says, ''Hey Maybe You Should Take A Break''. The Only Thing Controlling Your Will To Stop Or Keep Playing Is The Player's Own Demanding Ambition.

SOUNDTRACK
Half-Life soundtrack consists of a techno and ambience like tracks. One of Half Life's key elements two its atmosphere is said soundtrack. Half Life's soundtrack always seems to change conveniently creating a completely different mood and atmosphere to the last segment of the game. The use of ambience like tracks for the more creepy, mysterious moments through out the game coupled with the techno prodigy like tracks for the scripted action moments through out the game really create an experience like no other. Not two mention the end credits theme witch really feels rewarding and catchy... here is a link to the end credits theme soundtrack https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXpGM6NgrZ8
One of the best games of all time. Still holds up today, although the graphics are a bit outdated, the story and gameplay make up for it.

Ayant commencé par le deuxième, j'ai rattrapé mon retard en faisant les "origines" de Half Life 2, celui qui raconte comment notre Gordon Freeman national en est arrivé là. Et malgré une différence de 6 ans entre les deux opus, tout est là : environnement variés, renouvellement du gameplay, une panoplie d'armes impréssionante, une incroyable capacité à surprendre et un scénario bien mené et immersif qui vont laisseront scotché à votre fauteuil. Un jeu indispensable à votre culture vidéoludique que je conseille sans aucune hésitation, et pourtant je ne suis pas fan des univers de SF.

Although it may often feel today that Half Life is overshadowed by its phenomenal sequel, it remains a superb FPS and perhaps my favorite game of the 1990s.

The majority of the game involves theoretical physicst, Gordon Freeman, navigating through the winding corridors of the Black Mesa Research Facility while navigating hazards, completing puzzles, and fighting various enemies, both human and not. The journey can be a real challenge at times, especially if it your first time playing - however, the hardships encountered along the way make the game feel like a true adventure.

The combat, though dated, feels fast, exciting, and natural. Once you begin to acquire weaponry, learning which item in your arsenal is best in a given situation is quick and easy. Furthermore, the fact that the game gradually builds up your arsenal, from the humble but iconic crowbar to powerful experimental guns, lends the title a distinct sense of progression - something also present in Half Life 2.

As is typical of Valve games, the level-design is well thought out and immersive for the majority of the game. The tight and claustrophobic corridors of Black Mesa, littered with traps and enemies, are particularly good examples of this.

While a definite emphasis on the action is present, Half Life was notable at the time of its release for having a significant story amidst the conflict. The story, though mostly told through various NPCs scattered about the game, is also delivered through the design of the levels themselves and the actions of the player. 

In terms of animation and graphics, while the game is clearly dated at this point in time, the visuals have a certain early 3D charm that give the game a distinct and instantly recognizable feel. Furthermore, the age of the graphics do not detract from the experience since they fit within the game's world and are quickly accustomed to. 

Overall, while Half Life shows its age in terms of graphics, it is still incredibly fun to play and can be a real challenge at times. If you want to experience a great oldschool FPS from the 1990s, look no further than Half Life. I highly recommend it.

I strongly recommend this game. It is just as good as Half-Life 2, if not better, and you quickly become accustomed to the dated graphics. If you have a few extra dollars, buy the Half-Life 1 Anthology package. It's fifteen dollars, and contains Half-Life, Half-Life Blue Shift, Half-Life Opposing Force and Team Fortress Classic - you save about ten dollars from buying each individual game.
